content:
I am currently a reasearch Data scientist in the “Data Science for Social Impact and Philantropy” group led by Prof. Ciro Cattuto at the ISI foundation in Turin, Italy.
I obtained my PhD working in the GAIA team of GIPSA lab in Grenoble, under the supervision of Prof. Romain Couillet and of Nicolas Tremblay. My work focused on the improvement and theoretical understanding of unsupervised graph spectral clustering with methods at the frontier between graph signal processing, statistical physics, computer science and random matrix theory. Check here the page dedicated to my PhD manuscript.
Earlier I got a master degree in Physics of complex systems at Politecnico di Torino and Université Paris Sud. Check here the page dedicated to my Master degree thesis.
For few more details, download my CV.

content:
Face-to-face proximity interactions are the main driver of different types of contagion such as epidemic, social and opinion opinion contagion. The Sociopatterns collaboration developed proximity sensors that are capable to measure contact patterns with a high resolution in both time and space. We deployed these sensors in schools, hospital and offices, but the focus has also been towards sub-Saharan African countries such as Kenya, Malawi and South-Africa that have to tolerate the highest epidemic burdens.
The scope of this project is to study the proximity measurements to understand better how humans interact (especially in low-resources countries) and being able to devise efficient epidemic mitigation polices.
 Related works   Estimating household contact matrices structure from easily collectable metadata
summary: We measure human proximity to better understand human interactions with a particular interest to low-income countries
title: Study of f2f interactions

content:
Network theory is of central importance in interdisciplinary science. The ability of recovering properties of items starting from their interaction has key applications in many fields, ranging from biology, to social science, passing through electronics and Physics. Clustering is the ability to group the items of a system in categories sharing similar properties. The spectral techinques represent a fast solution to this problem. Solving this problem for sparse and heterogenous networks is of utmost importance to address the problem on real graphs.
 Related works At the following links you may find papers, slides, videos and codes related to my work in this project.

title: Spectral methods for graph clustering

content:
The market is a complex system in which many agents act with the purpose of maximizing their utility. The sum of the individuals’ actions, however, does not correspond to the behavior of the whole system that tends to a very fascinating self-organization that attracted the study of many theoretical physicists. Even if we are only at the beginning of such rigorous studies in this subject and only few stylized facts are known, the approach of physics proved to be able to give important elements in the microscopical modeling of financial market.
 This project was the intership of my Master thesis and I worked under the supervision of Michael Benzaquen and Antoine Fosset to create a model capable of predicting the everage shape of the limit order book, as well as explaining why the variation of the price goes as the square root of the traded volume and not linearly, as predicted by the Kyle model.
Related works   How does latent liquidity get revealed in the limit order book?  A mechanism for the latent liquidity revealing into the limit order book.
summary: Can we exploit statistical physics of complex systems to model the behavior of the financial market?
title: Limit order book models

summary: We examine the relationship between the political interest of social media users and their exposure to vaccine-hesitant content on Twitter, focusing on 17 European countries using a multilingual, longitudinal dataset of tweets spanning the period before COVID, up to the vaccine roll-out.
title: Political Issue or Public Health: the Vaccination Debate on Twitter in Europe

summary: We studied the association between of close-range contact patterns with SARS-CoV-2 transmission. We deployed proximity sensors for two weeks to measure face-to-face interactions between household members after SARS-CoV-2 was identified in the household, in South Africa, 2020–2021.
title: Association of close-range contact patterns with SARS-CoV-2: a household transmission study

summary: In this article we explore the impact that higher resolution, generalized contact matrices have on epidemic modeling.
title: Generalized contact matrices for epidemic modeling

summary: In this article we introduce a fast approximation method for the softmax normalization constants and use this result to define an efficient algorithm to create distributed representations.
title: Efficient distributed representations beyond negative sampling

summary: In this article we show how to reliably estimate contact matrices from easiliy collectable metadata. We exploit high resolution proximity measurements conducted in a rural and an urban village in South Africa.
title: Estimating household contact matrices structure from easily collectable metadata

summary: This manuscript presents the works conducted during my PhD.
title: Spectral methods for graph clustering

summary: In this article we show a relation between the Bethe approximation for Ising model on random graphs and the Nishimori temperature with applications to unsupervised correlation clustering.
title: Nishimori meets Bethe: a spectral method for node classification in sparse weighted graphs

summary: In this article we propose an new spectral algorithm to perform spectral clustering in sparse, dynamical graphs.
title: Community detection in sparse time-evolving graphs with a dynamical Bethe-Hessian

summary: In this article we provide a new interpretation on why regularization helps in sparse community detection as well as providing results on the optimal regularization to be adopted.
title: Optimal Laplacian regularization for sparse spectral community detection

summary: In this article we show how the benchmark spectral clustering techniques can all be explained under the same, elegant framework. We further provide a highly performing algorithm for community detection.
title: A unified framework for spectral clustering in sparse graphs

summary: In this article we propose an improved regularization of the Bethe-Hessian matrix to perform spectral clustering in sparse graphs.
title: Revisiting the Bethe-Hessian: Improved Community Detection in Sparse Heterogeneous Graphs

summary: This article proposes the study of the Bethe-Hessian matrix for community reconstruction applied on networks with arbitrary degree distribution.
title: Community detection in sparse realistic graphs: improving the Bethe-Hessian

summary: In this article we discuss and compare to real data a theoretical model describing the densities profile of actions in the limit order book
title: How does latent liquidity get revealed in the limit order book?

title: A mechanism for the latent liquidity revealing into the limit order book
